title: Issue verifying subcontracts

labels.name: status:needs-more-info
labels.description: There's not enough information to start working on this issue

body:
<!--

Thank you for using Hardhat and taking the time to open an issue!

**Note that this issue tracker is not a support channel.**

- For help with Hardhat and Hardhat network, please use our [Discord server](https://hardhat.org/discord).
- For help with ethers.js, please go to [its Github Discussions](https://github.com/ethers-io/ethers.js/discussions).

If you are reporting a bug, please include reproduction steps. The best way to do this is to include a [Minimal Reproducible Example](https://stackoverflow.com/help/minimal-reproducible-example). If you can't do that, then include a link to your repo, and the steps to reproduce the problem. The easiest it is to reproduce your problem, the faster we are going to be able to fix it.

If you are submitting a feature request, please take the time to clearly describe your use case, and not only your proposed solution.

This issue will be automatically assigned to a Hardhat team member. This person will act as the point of contact between you and the team, but won't necessarily fix it nor address it in any way. An issue being assigned does not mean that it's being worked on.

-->

## Problem

Hi all,

I believe I have found a problem regarding the verification of subcontracts, e.g. contracts deployed using the `new` keyword inside of another contract's function call.

Whenever I attempt to verify the contracts using hardhat-etherscan, the following error shows up:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/58761920/153693878-8fea479f-a392-44e2-90c5-55a7d716b1d1.png)

I am wondering if this is a hardhat issue or an etherscan / ftmscan issue, or hopefully, it is neither and I have just missed a crucial step.

## Troubleshooting

I have resolved this same error in the past by correcting the constructor arguments. As such this was my first thought, so I made sure that the constructor arguments I was passing in were indeed correct.

I found a [stack overflow issue](https://ethereum.stackexchange.com/questions/27991/how-do-you-verify-a-contract-on-etherscan-that-is-deployed-by-another-contract/43698) on the topic about the same issue which states that a few years ago it was an etherscan problem, however there is now conflicting advice saying it is indeed possible.

One of the recommendations was to manually encode the arguments, so instead of passing in my regular arguments I passed in the encoded arguments using:
`hre.ethers.utils.defaultAbiCoder.encode(["string"], ["Argument"]);`

Unfortunately, this was still not successful.

## Steps to reproduce

### Details

**It should be noted that the contract that deployed the subcontract was a proxy, however, I have seen this in [OpenZeppelin's own documentation](https://docs.openzeppelin.com/upgrades-plugins/1.x/writing-upgradeable#creating-new-instances-from-your-contract-code) for proxies as a perfectly accepted practice so I cannot see this causing the problem**

**It should be also noted that the contract's code got verified to Etherscan as a part of the verification process for the [implementation contract I deployed](https://ftmscan.com/address/0x6c8c4ef02069cfd5ea025eafb8ff4b0d9ab99dc7#code) (LPoolToken.sol), but yet this code won't verify for the contract itself**

- Network: Fantom mainnet
- Block explorer: Ftmscan
- [Contract that deployed subcontract (proxy)](https://ftmscan.com/address/0x5DF64a6D9A76f3808560DC071e2e67a7fF4a20A2)
- [Subcontract](https://ftmscan.com/address/0x034f91d348ce6e69b4972fe327a3014ddba5ec83)
- Subcontract code:
```solidity
//SPDX-License-Identifier: GPL-3.0-only
pragma solidity ^0.8.0;

import {ERC20} from "@openzeppelin/contracts/token/ERC20/ERC20.sol";
import {Ownable} from "@openzeppelin/contracts/access/Ownable.sol";

contract LPoolToken is ERC20, Ownable {
    constructor(string memory name_, string memory symbol_) ERC20(name_, symbol_) {}

    function mint(address account_, uint256 amount_) external onlyOwner {
        _mint(account_, amount_);
    }

    function burn(address account_, uint256 amount_) external onlyOwner {
        _burn(account_, amount_);
    }
}
```
- Function code that deployed the subcontract code:
```solidity
    // Add a new token to be used with the pool
    function addLPToken(
        address[] memory token_,
        string[] memory name_,
        string[] memory symbol_
    ) external onlyRole(POOL_ADMIN) {
        for (uint256 i = 0; i < token_.length; i++) {
            if (!isPT(token_[i]) && !isLP(token_[i])) {
                address LPToken = address(new LPoolToken(name_[i], symbol_[i]));

                _PTToLP[token_[i]] = LPToken;
                _LPToPT[LPToken] = token_[i];

                emit AddLPToken(token_[i], LPToken);
            }
        }
    }
```
- [Transaction where subcontract was deployed](https://ftmscan.com/tx/0x79491e82fe72685f4b418ac3da08636f8485ad93d3362554a65493e98f41b364)
- Constructor args: ["Torque Leverage Pool Wrapped Fantom", "tlpwFTM"]

### Steps

hardhat.config.ts
```typescript
import "@typechain/hardhat";
import "@nomiclabs/hardhat-ethers";
import "@nomiclabs/hardhat-etherscan";

import {task} from "hardhat/config";

import dotenv from "dotenv";
dotenv.config();

task("sandbox", "Testing sandbox", async (args, hre) => {
    await hre.run("verify:verify", {address: "0x034f91d348ce6e69b4972fe327a3014ddba5ec83", constructorArguments: ["Torque Leverage Pool Wrapped Fantom", "tlpwFTM"]});
});

const NETWORK_URL = "https://rpc.ftm.tools/";

export default {
    solidity: {
        compilers: [{version: "0.8.9", settings: {optimizer: {enabled: true, runs: 200}}}],
    },
    networks: {
        mainnet: {
            chainId: 250,
            url: NETWORK_URL,
            accounts: [process.env.PRIVATE_KEY],
        }
    },
    etherscan: {
        apiKey: {
            opera: process.env.FTMSCAN_API_KEY,
        },
    },
};
```

contracts/LPoolToken.sol
```solidity
//SPDX-License-Identifier: GPL-3.0-only
pragma solidity ^0.8.0;

import {ERC20} from "@openzeppelin/contracts/token/ERC20/ERC20.sol";
import {Ownable} from "@openzeppelin/contracts/access/Ownable.sol";

contract LPoolToken is ERC20, Ownable {
    constructor(string memory name_, string memory symbol_) ERC20(name_, symbol_) {}

    function mint(address account_, uint256 amount_) external onlyOwner {
        _mint(account_, amount_);
    }

    function burn(address account_, uint256 amount_) external onlyOwner {
        _burn(account_, amount_);
    }
}
```

CMD
```bash
NODE_OPTIONS=--openssl-legacy-provider npx hardhat sandbox --network mainnet
```

All help is much appreciated!

Hi @BenGOsborn, thanks for reporting this.

We don't have a `verify-all` task in `hardhat-etherscan`, only a `verify` one, so that task must come from some plugin. If that's the case, there isn't much we can do about it and you should probably open this issue in the plugin's repo.

Now, if the problem is that you deploy a contract from another contract using `new Bar()`, and then you can't verify that deployed contract using our `verify` task, that would be a problem. But that doesn't seem to be the case here?

> Hi @BenGOsborn, thanks for reporting this.
> 
> We don't have a `verify-all` task in `hardhat-etherscan`, only a `verify` one, so that task must come from some plugin. If that's the case, there isn't much we can do about it and you should probably open this issue in the plugin's repo.
> 
> Now, if the problem is that you deploy a contract from another contract using `new Bar()`, and then you can't verify that deployed contract using our `verify` task, that would be a problem. But that doesn't seem to be the case here?

Hey @fvictorio thanks for the reply,

The `verify-all` was just the command I used to run `sandbox` as a part of my deployment script, I apologize for the confusion.

To clarify, the issue I was referring to was the inability to use the `verify` task to verify a contract deployed from another contract using `new Bar()` for example.
Oh, I see, thanks for the clarification. I'll see if I can reproduce the problem.
Hmm I see. If that works then it means it's most likely an issue with the constructor arguments. I might play around with it and see if I can verify the contract manually from FTMScan first.
@BenGOsborn Closing this for now, please re-open if there is still a problem and you have reproduction steps. Thanks!
